Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Investigation and Optimization of Thermoelectric Properties of Highly-Doped Polysilicon Nanowires

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to develop a robust fabrication process for manufacturing micro-structures that will be used to measure the thermoelectric properties of polysilicon nanowires and subsequently to generate guidelines for optimizing the thermoelectric figure of merit in polysilicon nanowires. The effect of size, deposition parameters, and doping type/concentration on the figure of merit will be studied.

The intellectual merit is in filling the existing knowledge gap about thermoelectric properties of polysilicon nanowires. Such nanowires have an immediate application in developing high-performance IR sensors. Despite earlier reports on enhanced thermoelectric properties of silicon nanowires, there has been no report of practical thermoelectric devices that function based on such superior properties. This is mainly due to the complex process of growth and transfer of silicon nanowires, which hinders the batch-fabrication of such devices. The results of this research can potentially transform this status since polysilicon nanowires can be fabricated through conventional microfabrication processes and nanoscale lithography. This creates a unique opportunity for production of novel thermoelectric devices that take advantage of enhanced properties of nanowires.

The broader impact is envisioned in enabling low-cost and high-performance IR detectors with widespread usage in military, civilian, and medical diagnostic applications, where cost effective solutions with adequate performance do not exist. The funds received for the proposed research activities will also allow the PI to recruit and train local talents with priority given to underrepresented minorities and also will produce material for graduate level courses on micro/nano-systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of this project was to develop robust fabrication techniques for a micro-machined platform suitable for measuring the thermal conductivity of polysilicon at nanoscale and to generate guidelines for optimizing the thermoelectric figure of merit in polysilicon nanowires. In-line with this objective a very high-yield fabrication process was developed and using this process 100s of fully functional samples were prepared. A scanning electron micrograph of a typical fabricated microstructure is shown in the attached figure. Using such microstructures the thermal conductivity of nanoscale polysilicon films and wires were studied for the first time. Our results indicate that the measured thermal conductivity of polysilicon wires at thicknesses around 100nm (3-4 W/m.K) is very close to the limits measured for amorphous silicon. Moreover, our findings reveal that the thermal conductivity is mostly limited by out-of-plane phonon boundary scattering processes as the lateral dimension of the wire appeared to have little effect. In other word, the in-plane phonon scattering process appears to be mostly dominated by the grain boundary scattering as opposed to the lateral boundaries of the wire. This was confirmed by observation of a substantial increase in the measured thermal conductivity as a result of annealing the polysilicon film that led to grain size growth. Given our results we have concluded that very efficient thermoelectric sensors could be realized using fairly relaxed requirement on the lithographically-defined feature sizes as the lateral dimension of the thermoelectric polysilicon junctions would not significantly affect the overall thermal conductivity as long as the thickness of the film is reduced down to deep sub-micron. We have also characterized the thermal conductivity of the nanoscale polysilicon films down to liquid nitrogen cryogenic temperatures. Our measurement matches the earlier reports indicating the reduction of thermal conductivity at cryogenic temperatures, however the onset of the downward trend appears to have shifted toward higher temperature as a result of the nanoscale dimensions. The microstructure platform developed in this project could be potentially utilized for measuring thermal conductivity of a wide variety of material only restricted by process compatibility (i.e. resisting chemical etch in HF). The resources available through this project was also utilized for training two minority undergraduate students in our lab. We have also hosted a research day for high school students with the goal of inspiring them to chose STEM fields for their future careers.
